historySlides.text: Golf first appears on the front page of American newspapers when amateur Francis Ouimet defeats legendary British professionals Harry Vardon and Ted Ray at the 1913 U.S. Open. His victory reflects the rise of the United States as an economic and political powerhouse and heralds the arrival of golf’s golden age.
historySlides.title: Front Page News

historySlides.text: The 1920s marks the “Golden Age” of sports and sportswriters. The Great War has ended, the economy is booming, and fans everywhere wildly cheer athletes like Jack Dempsey (boxing), Suzanne Lenglen (tennis) and Babe Ruth (baseball). Golf’s great showman Walter Hagen proclaims, “I never wanted to be a millionaire. I just wanted to live like one.”
historySlides.title: An Era of Sports Heroes

historySlides.text: The art and science of golf course architecture flourish in the 1920s. Golden Age architects like Alister MacKenzie, Donald Ross and A.W. Tillinghast create masterpieces of design across North America, Europe, Asia and Australia. Natural forms and strategic options characterize iconic courses like Royal Melbourne, Cypress Point, Seminole and Winged Foot.
historySlides.title: Artists of the Golf Course

historySlides.text: The golden age of golf culminates in Bob Jones’ remarkable “Impregnable Quadrilateral,” as he records victories in the open and amateur championships of the United States and Great Britain in 1930. His “Grand Slam” is hailed widely as the greatest accomplishment in all of sport.
historySlides.title: A Grand Achievement

historySlides.text: It is a golden age for women’s golf. England’s Joyce Wethered and Glenna Collett Vare dominate on both sides of the Atlantic. Their rivalry—and friendship—elevates the visibility and appreciation of the women’s game. Marion Hollins creates Women’s National Golf and Tennis Club on Long Island, financed entirely by women.
historySlides.title: Women's Golf Strides Forward

historySlides.text: Following the formation of The Professional Golfers’ Association in the United Kingdom in 1901 and The Professional Golfers’ Association of America in 1916, professional golf flourishes. The game’s greatest professionals travel internationally, especially in the years that follow the Great War, leading to the creation of the Ryder Cup in 1927.
historySlides.title: The Rise of Professional Golf

eras_by_id.title: Golf’s <nobr>Golden Age</nobr>
eras_by_id.description: Heroes become household names in the era of sports celebrities

featuredImage.title: Player Golfs Golden Age Tommy Armour

accomplishments.name: Winner of the 1927 U.S. Open Championship
Winner of the 1930 PGA Championship
Winner of the 1931 Open Championship
Winner of the 1929 Western Open
Three-time winner of the Canadian Open
Author of best-selling book, "How To Play Your Best Golf All the Time"

directus_files_id.description: Tommy Armour playing at shot at Pinehurst No. 2, ca. 1930
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 Golfs Golden Age Tommy Armour

profiles.bioText:
Nicknamed the “Silver Scot” for the color of his hair, Tommy Armour possessed one of the finest golf swings of all time, as well as an uncanny ability to teach the game. He excelled at golf despite injuries he suffered in World War I that left him with sight in only one eye and metal plates in his head and arm. While recovering in the hospital, he focused on thoughts of playing golf. He would go on to win 27 professional events, including three major championships.

After he retired from competitive golf, Armour became one of the most successful instructors in the world. The philosophies and techniques that he taught were detailed in his best-selling book, **How to Play Your Best Golf All the Time.**
profiles.quote: It is not solely the capacity to make great shots that makes champions, but the essential quality of making very few bad shots.

directus_files_id.description: Portrait of Jim Barnes by George S. Pietzcker, ca. 1925

directus_files_id.description: Jim Barnes putts on the 17th green at Prestwick en route to victory in the 1925 Open Championship
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery4 Golfs Golden Age Jim Barnes

featuredImage.title: Player Golfs Golden Age Jim Barnes

accomplishments.name: Two-time winner of the PGA Championship
Winner of the 1921 U.S. Open Championship
Winner of the 1925 Open Championship
Three-time winner of the Western Open
Two-time winner of the North and South Open
Author of "Picture Analysis of Golf Strokes"

directus_files_id.description: Jim Barnes’ putting stroke, with a wide stance, hands held low, and his right forearm held against his right leg, ca. 1920
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 Golfs Golden Age Jim Barnes

directus_files_id.description: Jim Barnes admires the Claret Jug after winning the 1925 Open Championship at Prestwick
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 Golfs Golden Age Jim Barnes

profiles.bioText:
Towering over the competition at 6-foot-4, “Long Jim” Barnes won more than 25 professional tournaments in the era dominated by Gene Sarazen, Walter Hagen and Bob Jones. He won the inaugural PGA Championship in 1916 and successfully defended the title the next time it was played in 1919. In 1921, he won the U.S. Open by nine strokes and four years later captured the 1925 Open Championship coming from five strokes back in the final round.

Barnes was an intense, quiet competitor who often kept a sprig of clover clamped tightly between his teeth. In 1919, he authored **Picture Analysis of Golf Strokes**, revolutionary as the first golf instructional to make extensive use of photography.
profiles.quote: You can't always be playing well when it counts. You'll never win golf tournaments until you learn how to score well when you're playing badly.

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery3 Golfs Golden Age Leo Diegel

directus_files_id.description: Leo Diegel demonstrates his eponymous putting stroke during the 1929 U.S. Open at Winged Foot
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery4 Golfs Golden Age Leo Diegel

directus_files_id.description: Leo Diegel and Ted Ray on the 18th green at Worcester Country Club in the inaugural Ryder Cup Match in 1927

featuredImage.title: Player Golfs Golden Age Leo Diegel

accomplishments.name: Two-time winner of the PGA Championship
Four-time winner of the Canadian Open
Four-time member of the USA Ryder Cup Team
Winner of five tour events in 1925
Runner-up in 1920 U.S. Open and 1930 Open Championship
Won the 1916 Michigan Open at age 17

directus_files_id.description: Portrait of Leo Diegel by George S. Pietzcker, ca. 1930
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 Golfs Golden Age Leo Diegel

profiles.bioText:
Celebrated as one of the game’s great shot-makers, Leo Diegel will forever be remembered for his unorthodox putting stroke. His trademark style of putting, which came to be known as “Diegeling,” consisted of bending over at the waist and widely extending both arms with his elbows at right angles. 

Diegel’s peculiar technique earned him 30 PGA TOUR titles, including two PGA Championships, between 1920 and 1934. He also claimed four Canadian Open titles, as well as spots on four USA Ryder Cup Teams. After retiring in 1938, he became a club professional and worked with the U.S. Army during World War II to promote golf as a form of rehabilitation for wounded soldiers.
profiles.quote: In all my years of golf, I have never seen anyone whose devotion to the game could match Leo’s. Every night he went to bed dreaming theory and every morning he awakened with some hot idea that was going to revolutionize the game.

accomplishments.name: Winner of the 1916 U.S. Open and two-time winner of the U.S. Amateur
Eight-time Western Amateur champion
Winner of the 1910 Western Open
Three-time member of the USA Walker Cup Team
Recipient of the Bob Jones Award in 1960
Founder of the Evans Scholars Foundation providing college scholarship for caddies

directus_files_id.description: Timeless champion Chick Evans with the Western Open and Western Amateur trophies, 1962
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 Golfs Golden Age Chick Evans

directus_files_id.description: Chick Evans drives a golf ball from a man’s hand, ca. 1920
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 Golfs Golden Age Chick Evans

profiles.bioText:
Charles “Chick” Evans, whose competitive career spanned more than 50 years, was endowed with remarkable creativity and shot-making skills. In 1916, he became the first player to win the U.S. Open and U.S. Amateur in the same year. Evans remained at the highest level of competitive golf for decades, competing in every U.S. Amateur from 1907 through 1962 and establishing the championship’s record for most matches won (57). 

With the money Evans earned from producing golf instructional records and writing a golf book, he created a college scholarship for caddies. The Western Golf Association began administering the funds in 1929 and established the Evans Scholars Foundation, whose legacy includes helping more than 8,000 caddies receive a college education.
profiles.quote: I made a rule never to swing a golf club except to hit a golf ball, for I had learned that one could swing beautifully when the ball wasn’t there, and poorly when it was.

featuredImage.title: Player Golfs Golden Age Walter Hagen

accomplishments.name: Five-time winner of the PGA Championship
Four-time winner of the Open Championship
Two-time winner of the U.S. Open

accomplishments.description: Includes 5 wins at the Western Open in 1916. 1921, 1926, 1927 and 1932
accomplishments.name: Winner of 24 PGA Tour events
Five-time Playing Captain of the USA Ryder Cup team
Captain of the 1937 USA Ryder Cup team

directus_files_id.description: Portrait of Walter Hagen, ca. 1920
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 Golfs Golden Age Walter Hagen

profiles.bioText:
Walter Hagen, the greatest showman of golf’s “Golden Age," was legendary for his style and charisma. In fact, his reputation as a flamboyant and romantic character often overshadows his accomplishments on the course. Yet these were extraordinary. 

Hagen won 11 major championships and 45 tournaments during his career, including five Western Opens, an elite tournament that held near-Major status. He also captained the first six USA Ryder Cup Teams, posting a record of 7-1-1 in Ryder Cup competition. 

Hagen is justifiably remembered for his devotion to raising the profile of golf professionals and growing the game through nationwide exhibitions. “I never wanted to be a millionaire,” Hagen once wrote, “I just wanted to live like one.”
profiles.quote: You’re only here for a short visit. Don’t hurry. Don’t worry. And be sure to smell the flowers along the way.

accomplishments.name: Winner of the 1920 PGA Championship

Popularized deep-groove irons, which were subsequently banned by the R&A
Honorary Starter at the Masters from 1963–1973

directus_files_id.description: Jock Hutchison plays a long approach, ca. 1920
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 Golfs Golden Age Jock Hutchison

directus_files_id.description: Jock Hutchison, ca. 1920
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 Golfs Golden Age Jock Hutchison

profiles.bioText:
St. Andrews native Jock Hutchison immigrated to the United States in the early 1900s and became a naturalized American citizen in 1920. He would go on to win 14 tournaments on the PGA TOUR, including two consecutive major championships. In 1921, Hutchinson became the first U.S.-based player to capture the Claret Jug with his victory at the 1921 Open Championship. 

Known around the course as "Jovial Jock," Hutchison won the inaugural Senior PGA Championship in 1937, and did so again in 1947. He returned to Augusta National Golf Club–the site of his 1937 victory–when he joined 1908 U.S. Open champion Fred McLeod as the first honorary starters at the Masters in 1963.
profiles.quote: When he shifted into a brilliant streak, Jock could play one perfect hole after another, each shot, like mountain views in Switzerland, seemingly more breathtaking than the one that went before.

featuredImage.title: Player Golfs Golden Age Bob Jones

accomplishments.name: Four-time winner of the U.S. Open Championship
Five-time winner of the U.S. Amateur Championship
Three-time winner of the Open Championship
Winner of the 1930 Amateur Championship

accomplishments.description: Jones represented the USA in 1922, 1924, 1926, 1928, and 1930, captaining the team in 1928 and 1930
accomplishments.name: Five-time member of the USA Walker Cup Team
Co-founder of the Augusta National Golf Club and The Masters Tournament

directus_files_id.description: Need Caption
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 Golfs Golden Age Bob Jones

directus_files_id.description: Bob Jones poses with the Grand Slam trophies in 1930; from left to right: Open Championship, U.S. Amateur Championship, Amateur Championship, U.S. Open Championship
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 Golfs Golden Age Bob Jones

profiles.bioText:
More than any player in history, Robert Tyre "Bob" Jones Jr. remains the model of a complete golfer and the quintessential champion. A man of intelligence, character and pure athleticism, Jones merged all three traits to become not only a singular champion, but a genuine hero. 

A lawyer by trade, Jones won five U.S. Amateurs, one Amateur Championship, four U.S. Opens and three Open Championships. In 1930, he did the near-impossible and claimed all four majors in a single year, then promptly retired from competitive golf. Together with his partner Clifford Roberts, Jones would go on to found Augusta National Golf Club and the Masters, enlisting Alister MacKenzie to assist in the course design.
profiles.quote: What Jones did was create a model that everyone, consciously or unconsciously, followed. It is why we have so many fine people in golf. He showed the world how to do it.

directus_files_id.description: Francis Ouimet’s scorecard from the 1913 U.S. Open playoff; Hall of Fame member Bernard Darwin was his marker

directus_files_id.description: Francis Ouimet with his daughters Janice and Barbara (swinging), 1929
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 Golfs Golden Age Francis Ouimet

directus_files_id.description: Need Caption
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 Golfs Golden Age Francis Ouimet

profiles.bioText:
Francis Ouimet began his golf career as an 11-year-old caddie at The Country Club, just across the street from his home in Brookline, Massachusetts. He brought new levels of attention to the game when, as a 20-year-old amateur, he defeated British legends Harry Vardon and Ted Ray in an 18-hole playoff at The Country Club in the 1913 U.S. Open. It would mark the first time that golf appeared on the front page of American newspapers.

Following that historic victory, Ouimet went on to capture the U.S. Amateur in 1914 and 1931 while pursuing other business ventures. In 1951, he became the first non-Briton elected Captain of The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews.
profiles.quote: To me, the ground here is hallowed. The grass grows greener, the trees bloom better, and there is even warmth to the rocks. Somehow or other the sun seems to shine brighter on The Country Club than any other place that I have ever known.

directus_files_id.description: Hall of Fame members and friends Gene Sarazen, Tommy Armour and Johnny Farrell, ca. 1930
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery1 Golfs Golden Age Gene Sarazen

directus_files_id.description: Gene Sarazen celebrates his first major championship victory, the 1922 U.S. Open at Skokie Country Club in Glencoe, Illinois

directus_files_id.description: Gene Sarazen at work on his farm in upstate New York, his second passion after golf
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery3 Golfs Golden Age Gene Sarazen

featuredImage.title: Player Golfs Golden Age Gene Sarazen

accomplishments.name: Three-time winner of the PGA Championship
Two-time winner of the U.S. Open Championship
Winner of the 1935 Masters Tournament
Winner of the 1932 Open Championship
Six-time member of the USA Ryder Cup Team
Recipient of the Bob Jones Award in 1992

directus_files_id.description: Portrait of Gene Sarazen by George S. Pietzcker, 1922
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 Golfs Golden Age Gene Sarazen

profiles.bioText:
Born Eugenio Saraceni, the son of an Italian carpenter from Rome, Gene Sarazen spanned golf history as a competitor, innovator and senior statesman. He had a compact but ferocious swing and a fiercely competitive but generous heart.

In the final round of the 1935 Masters, Sarazen holed a miraculous shot from 220 yards for double eagle on the 15th hole. He finished the round tied with Craig Wood, then won the playoff the next day to become the first player to win all four major championships. 

In 1931, while being taught by Howard Hughes how to fly a plane, Sarazen came upon the idea for the modern sand wedge. He later called it his biggest contribution to the game.
profiles.quote: When Sarazen saw a chance at the bacon hanging over the last green, he could put as much fire and fury into a finishing round as Jack Dempsey could put into a fight.

directus_files_id.description: Jerry Travers with the U.S. Open trophy at Baltusrol Golf Club, 1915
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery1 Golfs Golden Age Jerry Travers

accomplishments.name: Winner of the 1915 U.S. Open Championship
Four-time winner of the U.S. Amateur Championship
Five-time winner of the Metropolitan Amateur Championship
Four-time winner of the New Jersey State Amateur Championship
Qualified for match play in the 1903 U.S. Amateur at age 16
Participated in numerous exhibition matches to raise funds for the Red Cross during World War I

directus_files_id.description: Jerry Travers demonstrates how to play a stymie, lofting his shot over an opponent’s ball, ca. 1910
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 Golfs Golden Age Jerry Travers

profiles.bioText:
One of the most feared golfers of his generation, Jerry Travers captured four U.S. Amateurs, five Metropolitan Amateurs and a U.S. Open between 1906 and 1915. He had a brilliant short game, but was erratic off the tee. In 1915, Travers became the second amateur to win the U.S. Open, but he chose to not defend his title and subsequently retired from competitive golf. 

As Herbert Warren Wind explained, it was a fierce rivalry with Walter Travis that “formed the crucible in which a talented young golfer was made into the greatest match player of his decade.” Among his peers, Jerry Travers earned ultimate, almost intimidating, respect. Chick Evans called him “the coldest, hardest golfer I ever knew.”
profiles.quote: Golf is a game of the head as well as a game of the hands.

directus_files_id.description: Pencil sketch of Walter Travis by Louis Holz, ca. 1920
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery1 Golfs Golden Age Walter Travis

accomplishments.name: Three-time winner of the U.S. Amateur Championship

Author of "Practical Golf" and "The Art of Putting" and founder of "The American Golfer" magazine

directus_files_id.description: Walter Travis, ca. 1900
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 Golfs Golden Age Walter Travis

profiles.bioText:
There has not been a golfer who played so well after starting so late in life as Walter J. Travis. He took up golf at age 34, won his first tournament one month later and two years later reached the semifinal round of the U.S. Amateur. Within four years, Travis won the first of three U.S. Amateur titles. He was the first American citizen to win The Amateur Championship and ended his career by winning the prestigious Metropolitan Amateur at age 53. 

Travis retired from competitive golf in 1916, but went on to design or renovate more than 50 golf courses. He published several books and founded the magazine **The American Golfer** to share his knowledge of the game.
profiles.quote: Always be on the aggressive. Act as if you are quite sure of yourself and never give an opponent the psychological advantage of imagining you are the least afraid of him.

contentTrails.name: Architects & Designers
contentTrails.description: Hall of Famers who shaped the landscape of golf through iconic courses and crafted the equipment that has defined the evolution of the game

contentTrails.name: Military Figures
contentTrails.description: Hall of Famers whose off-the-course contributions included service to their countries

contentTrails.name: Growth Drivers
contentTrails.description: Ambassadors for the game who have spread its impact to new players, new audiences and new parts of the world

contentTrails.name: Teachers
contentTrails.description: Players and other contributors who left their mark through teaching tools, writings and face-to-face instruction and coaching

contentTrails.name: Voices of the Game
contentTrails.description: Writers, commentators and others who, through their words, shape our understanding of golf's most memorable moments

contentTrails.name: Comeback Stories
contentTrails.description: Hall of Famers who etched their legacy by overcoming setbacks, personal hardships and impossible  odds
